PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  The Government of the Maldives has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
undertake project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA), to conduct due diligence for the 
development of district roads and harbor project in Laamu Gan-Fonadhoo islands. This project 
will bring about inclusive socioeconomic benefits to the inhabitants in Laamu Atoll region.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $600,000 equivalent and will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF); $72,000 from TASF-V and $528,000 from 
TASF-others. The government will provide support in the form of counterpart staff, office and 
housing  accommodation,  office  supplies,  secretarial  assistance,  domestic  transportation, 
provision of office space, and communication facilities for PPTA consultants. The detailed cost 
estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  One international individual consultant (1.5 person-months) will be recruited to review the 
regional development plan and to scope and prepare an investment plan for the subsequent 
project design phase. An international consulting firm will then be engaged to implement the 
PPTA. The services will require 7 international consultants (14 person-months) and 4 national 
consultants (12  person-months).  ADB  will  use quality-  and  cost-based  selection  (90:10)  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time) due to the need for higher quality consultant services because of the project’s complexity. 
A simplified technical proposal will be required. Lump sum payments/output-based contracts will 
be considered for consulting services. Table A3.3 shows the summary of consulting services 
requirement.

10  Appendix 3 
5.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras. 6 to 14. 
The detailed individual consultant terms of reference will be prepared at the time of issuance of 
the request for proposal. 
6.  Regional Development Specialist/Economist (international, 1.5 person-months). The 
international consultant will have a bachelor’s degree in economics, business management, 
regional development, or related discipline, and 10 years of experience in investment appraisal 
and project evaluations. The consultant will review and prioritize investment options from the 
regional development perspective and identify an economically viable investment plan.  
7.  Engineer/Team Leader (international, 6 person-months). The international consultant 
will have a bachelor’s degree or above in engineering with at least 20 years of experience in 
road planning and design, managing multidisciplinary team and administering large civil works 
projects. The  consultant  will  prepare  engineering feasibility  studies  and  road  designs,  and 
provide inputs to ADB processing documents. 
8.  Procurement Expert (international, 3 person-months). The international consultant will 
have (i) a bachelor’s degree in civil engineering, (ii) a minimum of 10 years of professional 
experience in this expertise, and (iii) adequate knowledge of ADB’s procurement procedures. 
Having working experiences in ADB’s developing member countries are preferable. The expert 
will establish civil work contract packaging and consulting service packaging, assess the needs 
for consultant inputs for construction supervision, and prepare bidding documents. 
9.  Environmental Specialist (international, 1 person-month; national, 2 person-months). 
The international consultant will have a master’s degree or above and at least 10 years related 
experience  in  preparing  environmental  impact  assessment  for  small  island  countries  and 
relevant environmental report preparation and implementation. The national consultant will have 
a  bachelor’s  degree  in  a  relevant  field,  and  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  preparing 
environmental impact assessment for infrastructure development project in the Maldives. The 
consultants will prepare environmental safeguards requirement as described in ADB’s SPS. 
10.  Involuntary  Resettlement  Specialist  (international,  1  person-month;  national,  2 
person-months). The international consultant will have appropriate degree qualification and 10 
years  related  experience  in  involuntary  resettlement  preparation  and  implementation.  The 
national consultant will have a bachelor’s degree in social development, and experience in 
preparing resettlement reports for government projects in the Maldives. The consultants will 
prepare all requirements related with social safeguards particularly involuntary resettlement as 
described in ADB’s SPS.  
11.  Social  Development  Specialist  (poverty,  participatory,  gender,  and  labor 
specialist)  (international,  1  person-month;  national,  2  person-months).  The  international 
consultant  will  have  a  second  level  degree  in  social  development  and  10  years  related 
experience  in  preparing  poverty  and  social  assessment  for  ADB  projects.  The  national 
consultant will have a bachelor degree in social sciences and at least 3 to 5 years of experience 
in  dealing  with  social  development  issues  such  as  poverty,  gender,  labor  and  public 
participation. The consultants will prepare all project requirements on social aspects other than 
social safeguards, and prepare poverty and social assessment report with clear assessment on 
the project impacts on poverty reduction, gender equality, compliance with core labor standards, 
and community participatory.  
12.  Transport  Economist/Financial  Specialist  (international,  1  person-month).  The 
international  consultant  will  have  a  bachelor’s  degree  or  above  in  economics,  financial

management, or closely related fields, and 8 years related experience in conducting economic 
and financial analysis of similar transport projects. The consultant will prepare an economic 
analysis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects and other 
relevant  publications. The  consultant  will  (i)  review  the  cost  estimates  and financing  plan; 
(ii) review the implementation arrangements; (iii) review the fund flow mechanism, auditing, and 
disbursement arrangements; (iv) review the risk analysis, financial risks and mitigation, and 
covenants; (v) review financial analysis; (vi) assess the executing and implementing agencies 
capability to manage imprest funds and statement of expenditures procedures, and financial 
management assessment; and (vii) review other financial due diligence of the project. 
13.  Climate  Change  Specialist  (international,  1  person-month).  The  international 
consultant  will  have  a  master’s  degree  or  above  in  environmental sciences/engineering  or 
related  field(s)  to  climate  change,  and  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in  designing  and 
implementing  infrastructure  projects  especially  in  the  road  sector  using  climate  change 
adaptation techniques. The consultant tasks will focus but not be limited to: (i) assessing the 
sensitivity of project components to climate change risks; (ii) evaluating and classifying the level 
of impacts to the project from climate change; (iii) developing of a climate risk framework to help 
better cope with climate variability and change through selected measures; and (iv) calculating 
the costs for adopting the measures identified. 
14.  Civil  Engineer/Deputy  Team  Leader  (national,  6  person-months).  The  national 
consultant will have a bachelor’s degree or above in science and/or business management and 
at least 8 years of experience in managing and implementing projects. The consultant will assist 
the team leader in coordinating project activities and preparing and submitting to ADB required 
documents and developing project cost estimates. 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT) (executing agency) and the Ministry of 
Housing and Infrastructure (MOHI) (implementing agency) have implemented a number of ADB-
assisted transport projects. MOHI will appoint a project manager dedicated to the PPTA to 
monitor the day-to-day progress of implementation and prepare necessary documents and 
reports. The project manager will oversee the consultants’ activities and facilitate all facets of 
PPTA administration with the support of additional staff appointed by MOFT and MOHI. MOHI 
will provide (i) counterpart staff who will work closely with the consultants; (ii) office facilities in 
Male; and (iii) local transport for field trips. Disbursements will be done in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The proposed 
PPTA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A3.4.  
 
Table A3.4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule
